content:
Richard thrashes
some spicier Minis,

and I get sideways
in the latest Lamborghini.

Hello! Now don't worry, we have got
some Minis in the programme as well.

But it is Lamborghini's 40th
anniversary this year,

so we thought it would be
a good idea

to have a look at some
of the cars they made

over the years, and do a bit of a tribute
to the maddest car company of them all.

This is the origin of
Lamborghini as we know it today.

More than that, it's where
the modern supercar begins.

It's the first, the daddy,
the Miura.
13th of June, 1967.

That was the day the first
Miura arrived in Britain.

And just imagine that body shape
coming down your High Street in 1967.

Only the sight of Harold Wilson on
LSD could have caused more of a stir.

And as befits the decade that
celebrated being young and groovy,
youth created the Miura.

The man who designed its
gorgeous body was just 22.

Think about that.
What were you doing at 22?

At that age, the cars I was
drawing still had guns on them.

The engineers behind
him were in their 20s too.

And the Miura wasn't even an
official project.

Just seven lads working
after hours for the fun of it.

They didn't
realise it at the time,

but those seven impetuous
young engineers

were about to spark
a revolution.

Until then, all seriously fast cars had
their big, heavy engines here at the front.

But the Miura had its V12
here, in the middle,

setting the template for all
future supercars.

They also mounted the engine
sideways rather than lengthways,
to keep the car compact.

Mind you, they nicked that
idea from the Mini.

But we'll let them
have that one.

There was other radical stuff
that didn't see the light of day.

The first design had a three-seater
layout, like a McLaren F1.

And it had a glass engine
cover, like a Ferrari 360.

This did make it, though.
The shape of the doors.

See? They're supposed to
look like the horns of a bull. Nice.

So, beautiful and ingenious
it may have been,

but in terms of driving,
you were still at the wheel
of a bit of a dog's breakfast.

The fuel tank was over the front
wheels, so as it ran low on fuel

it went light at the front end,
which meant you couldn't steer.

Nice touch, that.
Keeps you on your toes.

The interior is, well, tiny. And every
now and again the carburettors would

spit petrol onto the hot engine, and
the whole thing would go up in flames.
Good.

It is not
an easy car to drive.
But, it sounds...
Like that. Oh!

Lamborghini knew their
masterpiece wasn't perfect

and they steadily improved it
throughout its life,

culminating in this,
the SV of 1971.

It had a better gearbox, better differential,
better tyres, better rear suspension.

And these better gold wheels. Do
you know what it was? It was better.

And like all Miuras, it was the car
of choice for a better sort of person.

People like Frank Sinatra,
Rod Stewart, and this bloke.
That is such a glorious noise.

Jamiroquai front man
Jay Kay is a huge Miura fan.

This car was so
ahead of its time, you know.

You can imagine
sitting there, in a...

In a Wolseley 1800
or a TR6 in 1972,

and this turns up at the lights, you
know. Hopefully with Twiggy in it.

Which would have been
delightful. I mean, can you imagine?
I think I'd have fainted.

♪ Get your motor running
Head out on the highway
♪ Take whatever comes my way

It's a wonderful, wonderful thing.
And I don't buy cars to speculate.

I don't buy cars like these
fools, and they hide them away.
The kids today don't see them.

They'll never know what it's
like to see a Lamborghini Miura

busting past you at 130-40
miles an hour.

This, to me, shouts out,
"Matchbox car, 1972".

- There I am, on the carpet.
- You remember it?

You know, I mean, that's
what it shouts out to you.

- Now you got a big one.
- And there it is. And now I got a big one.

Um, Jay, I did notice there's,
uh... There's no window in.

Well, I'll tell you
what I did with the window.

- Re-enact it for us. Go on then.
- I will re-enact it.

Oh, you closed the door? You
mad, impetuous rock star fool.

- You're asking for trouble, Jay!
- You know, I mean,
that's rock 'n roll.

The Miura lived a short life, just six
years in production, during which time

761 were made.
That's all.

But it established
Lamborghini in massive style.

My journey in the Miura has
brought me from chez Jay Kay

to Duxford Airbase
in Cambridgeshire,

because the car has
a kindred spirit living here.

There are certain machines
that are so radical,

that make such an impact
when you see them,

that you know things
will never be the same again.

Machines like this.
It's the prototype Concorde.

Imagine how people felt the
first time this flew overhead.

It looked so different,
so breathtaking,

and the thinking behind it
was so fresh
that it changed the world.

Concorde did it for planes.
The Miura did it for supercars.
As a car, it was flawed.

But as a concept,
it was truly a masterpiece.

So, is Jay Kay still smarting about
his humiliating defeat on our track?

I can't say for sure, but he went
very, very fast in his Miura. So...

But you see, that's the thing. I went
even faster with Jodie the other day.

Jodie Kidd made 2,000 miles
an hour on Concorde, in fact.
Yeah, all right.

So I managed to win that one too, which
actually brings me on to a good point.

What is the best-looking
machine ever made by man?

- Spitfire.
- Spitfire?

- Beautiful-looking...
- Anyone else got any thoughts?

- The Blackbird.
- Hold on a minute, say that again.

- The Blackbird. The SR71.
- The Blackbird?

The SR71. The spy plane.
You familiar with that?

- Yes, I am.
- It is an immensely good-looking thing.

What about cars? Come on,
best-looking cars then.

- TVR.
- TVR? What?
You can't be saying...

Who said TVR? Oh, it was Ray
Charles, who's joined us this week.

We think we've worked this one
out. Three best-looking cars ever.

- Ford GT40. Yes, all nod.
- I do agree with that, actually, yeah.

- Yes. Aston Martin DB7.
- Yeah, again, you're right.

- What do you mean?
Who said no?

- Hold it.
- Who... You said no. Why?

Because you're always on
about it. You like it too much.

You know, it's an Aston.
And it's Ford. You know, it's...

This is a man with a two-tone
beard, who's come along here
to tell us about style.

Um... Anyway, let's get back
to it. My point is...
DB7. Ford GT40. And this.
I think you're right...

Yes, thank you. This.
And the reason...

The reason
why it's so graceful,

if you look at it in profile, is
because it's the exact same shape
as an aeroplane's wing.

Which is another reason
why it tends to take off.

- Once you get to, like, 80 miles an hour.
- Yes, it does.
It generates its own lift.

In fact, remember
The Italian Job,

at the beginning of it,
the bloke, bulldozer.

In real life,
the car would probably

have just flown straight over the
bulldozer and missed him completely.

- Probably even right over the mountain.
- Another Alp.

So if you were to buy one of these,
and you'd buy one now for how much?

A good SV, the better one, would cost
you about £100,000. Something like that.

Okay, if you were to spend
£100,000 on a car like this,

- you wouldn't really drive it anywhere.
- Oh, heavens, no!

- What I would do... Put it in the garden.
- Good idea.

- An ornament.
- Oh, nice.

Because... What's that
programme? Gardening Force.

- Where they put gravel everywhere?
- Yeah, they put gravel...

What's it called? Ground
Force. Ground Force.

- That, with Charlie Dimmock's features.
- All right.
What?

Anyway, forget the gravel,
forget the fountains,

get one of these, put it
in your garden, look at it.

It's even better to look at in the
bushes than a Lightning jet fighter.

And so to the news. Now, I'm
sure you're aware on this programme

we're not particular fans of the
personalised registration number.

We don't play golf. However,
some people out there

do have a handicap,
and the DVLA

is only too happy to serve them.
In fact, they're having an auction

of special number plates, and
they say they've got something

for the music enthusiast.
Have a look at this.

Now, I'm slightly baffled,
because I didn't know

that drum kits had
to be registered,

- for one thing.
And also,

I can't quite see
the music connection,

because this number plate is
for a bloke called Les,

who lives somewhere off
the B347.

The DVLA says that that says,
"Beatles".

- But I'd like to suggest...
- It just doesn't, does it?

B... If I were following
a car that said,

"B347 LES" on it, I wouldn't
think... It's Ringo Starr!
Exactly.

Can we have a look at some of
the others that are coming out?

And I want you to see if you
can guess what they actually say.

These are being sold by the
DVLA. Look at that.

- This...
- This I don't get. This I don't, because I...

This was up for sale
for £22,000.

So you have a bit
of an embarrassing problem.

You drive around going,
"My dicky doesn't work,

"and I'm spending £22,000
advertising the fact."

- I wonder if you can get "floppy" on one.
- Yes, "floppy".

- It is more or less.
- You'd be driving a floppy...

You'd be driving a car
with a big bonnet.

- Let's have another one.
- Come on, let's have another one.

What's that?
There's no "I" in "toast"!

Do you wanna know? £1,125.
And even if it did say "toast"...

- Why do you want "toast" on your car?
- You're gonna be toast!

- You might as well have "broccoli".
- What a stupid

- word to have on the back of your car.
- "Blancmange".

- What's another one?
- "Hat".

- "Stamps".
- That's even more idiotic!

- What are you...
- It doesn't say stamps, but even if it did!

It's just a random...
"Elbow"!

- Oh, well, that's right.
- £1,200. Stamps.

- £1,200?
- Oh, yeah, P147 BOY. I've met him.

The point I want to make here is,
here we've got a government agency

selling us these number plates
on the basis that you can tweak

around with them to make
them say something else.

Then you have another government
agency, with tall hats and plastic shoes,

booking you for changing your
number plate around
so it says "stamps".

Absolutely right.
Welcome to Britain.
Welcome to Britain, everybody.

- This is the worst country in the world.
- Yes.

I've got another
example of that.

There was a rally
last weekend in Britain.

It was the final round of the
World Rally Championship,

and it was won by
a man driving...

- A car?
- A car.

These rallies, for those
of you who don't know,

the idea is, you drive as fast
as possible around a wood.

Then you drive on normal roads
to the next wood,

where you drive as fast
as possible again.

Now, on the roads, you're expected
to behave in a responsible fashion.

Everywhere else in the world,
thousands and thousands and thousands

of spectators roll up to watch
the cars go through their villages

- and along the motorways.
- It's like a fiesta.

- Like a party.
- Exactly. It's a big thing.

Britain, okay? What they did in
Wales, where the rally was last year,

was they sent a police
speed-trap van down...
Oh, God.

Where they caught,
and I'm...

I've got the report here.
They caught 17 drivers, okay?
Seventeen of them speeding.

Some of them were doing
40 miles an hour.
World-class sportsmen

come to this country to indulge
in a pastime that all over the world

- is greeted by, "Oh, marvellous, let's watch."
- And they send out...

They go out and they book you. And
do you know something extraordinary?

Most of these people went back
to their huts in Finland

or wherever they
come from, okay,

thinking, "Well, it
doesn't really matter.

"I've been nicked for speeding
in England." But oh, no!

Soon as they came back for
this year's event, "You're nicked."

And they were all in court.
This bloke, Loix, okay,

who's a Belgian rally driver,
he was caught,

uh, seven times on the same
stretch in the same morning.

So they fined him £1,750
and gave him a six-month ban.

And this is the way we welcome
world-class sportspeople.

Exactly. Welcome.
Come and...

- What are they gonna do next?
- At the Olympics,

- they'll be standing there near the swimming pool.
- Exactly.

- "That bloke's doing 33 there."
- No, well...

"And with that javelin,
offensive weapon. I'll have that."

Right, I've got a car here. VW
are wondering whether to make this.

They're scratching their heads thinking,
"Oh, I'm not sure." Well, don't be stupid!

Make it. It's got a V6. It's a...
Every... We love these cars.

Do you know something a bit interesting
about this? Just stop the film there.

There, because the steering
wheel, okay, and the pedals move,
and the seats don't.

Nobody but you would find that
too complicated to grasp.

I'm sorry. Why do you have... For
years we have seats that move about.

This lot then said, "No, no,
we'll fix the seats in place,

"and then you move the whole
dashboard", and that's ridiculous.

I just know you'd end up
sitting, "I can't work it, me seat..."

That's what I'm saying. I'm
too far from the television,

I'll knock my house down and move
the whole thing 6 inches nearer to it.

And your poor ageing
brain can't cope.

What's that thing that you drove last year
that was about that big and you loved it?

- Per...
- Oh, the Perodua.

Perodua. Okay, Perodua Kelisa.
He drove one. He absolutely loved it.

Well, they've launched
a new car.

Round about £6,000.
We've got a picture of it here.

It's called the Kenari, okay.
Sounds like a food blender.

Um... They say it's
a multi-purpose vehicle.

Now, I can see one use for it. You could
use it to stop a door banging in the wind.

But... I'm struggling
to think of another use.

You could keep
a chicken in it.

- Yes.
- Just one.

You couldn't put two in, otherwise
it'd be a battery and it'd be illegal.

Yeah. Anyone else
got any thoughts?

No, lower the windows
by 3 inches all around,

- and it'd be a bottle bank.
- Yes.

Not sure it's gonna
work as a car, though,

which is what I think they've
got in mind for it. Anyway...

- Oh, that's a ridiculous idea.
- Yeah.
But, speaking of small cars...

The bestselling car has been announced
for... I think September of this year.
Right, the bestselling car.

Anyone wanna hazard
a guess what it was?

- It's...
- The bestselling car, in Britain, in September.

- Vectra.
- Vectra? Wrong.

- Focus.
- Focus? Wrong.

He's... He's just said it.
It's the Corsa.
What is that saying?
Has anybody here got one?
No.

Somebody said no a bit
too quickly there.

There it is. Look,
the majesty of it.

You know when they run those
adverts for it, what it should say is,

"Show the world you know
nothing about cars."

- Yeah.
- Buy a Vauxhall Corsa.

So we thought it'd be
a good idea tonight,

if anybody has inadvertently
strayed into the programme

from Heartbeat or Monarch
of the Glen or whatever

depressing thing they're
showing on Channel 4,

and you're thinking of buying a
small car, what should you buy?

- Honda Jazz.
- Honda... Definitely. That's pricey too.

It's over £10,000,
but fantastically versatile.

Is it? Whatever,
£9,000-10,000. It is expensive.
Micra. Fantastic little car.

The Micra is unbelievably
well-equipped. You get air-conditioning,

and you get keyless-go
and things.

That's very good.
But actually my favourite,

and I'm not doing this
in any particular order,

my favourite is the
Toyota Yaris.

Ah, I'm with you there.
It's a fabulous little car.

So there you are. Top Gear audience, if
you wanna buy a small car, for God's sake,

- stop doing this.
- No.

Think about what you're saying about yourself
and what you're saying about your nation.

Right. That's enough of that. Now, back
in 1980, I was a mere lad, with a bedroom

to decorate. Now, of course, in those
days, there was no changing rooms

and no Mediterranean hues. All you could
really do was slap a poster on the wall.

And what's more, there were
only two to choose from.

The first one was this one
of a lady playing tennis.
And the other one was this.
The Lamborghini Countach.

The early eighties were a
troubled time. The miner's strike,

John Lennon shot,
and the Falklands war.

But that was just the stuff on the news.
The really important issue of the day was,

which was cooler? The Ferrari
Boxer or the Lamborghini Countach?

Lamborghini had succeeded
in dividing the loyalties

of pubescent
British schoolboys.

Fights were breaking out
behind bike sheds.

People were defacing
one another's posters.

That was the impact
this thing had.

Here's how they squared up.
Ferrari had absolutely nothing to prove.

It had a long history, the
race breeding, the pedigree,

and it was run by Enzo, a godfather
figure with purple ink in his fountain pen.

The Boxer had a flat-12
engine and styling by Pininfarina.
It was a true thoroughbred.

And now the Countach. Oh, by the way, I've
never actually driven one of these before.

I've been waiting 20 years,
to pop me Countach cherry.

Where the Ferrari was an aristocrat,
the Countach was an upstart.

Lambo may have done the Miura,
but they still weren't quite pucker.

So to make up for that,
it had to be flashy.

Quite simply, it had to be the
world's most outrageous supercar.

And it was. This wasn't
just a car. It was a pin-up.

And you might like to know that
Countach is a bit of Italian slang.

It translates roughly
as "phwoar".
This is Letchworth.

It was the first garden city
in the world,

and the site of
the world's first roundabout,

a model of English
middle-class suburbia.

For a long time,
it didn't even have a pub.

A Countach fits in
with all this

like a youth with a bad
haircut and a can of spray paint.

But even here, there was
a time in the early '80s

when every boy's bedroom would have
had a piece of pornography on the wall,
a Countach poster.

In the
Countach-Boxer battle,

places like Letchworth were a
landslide victory for the Lambo.

It just looked
so much cooler.

Oh, sure, more and more cosmetic
bits were added during its 18-year life,

but so what?
This was the '80s.

We thought
Kevin Keegan's perm was cool.

I was always in
the Countach camp,

and I can tell you
off the top of my head

that this one's
an LP400 S.

It does 180 miles per hour
and 0-60 in 4.6 seconds.

It also has some of the fattest rear
tyres ever fitted to a production car,
at 345 millimetres.
Listen to that!

I absolutely knew it would sound
like that just by looking at the pictures.
So, it looks fantastic
and it sounds fantastic.

And that's what matters
when you're 15 and dreaming.
But I'm not 15 anymore,

and after an hour at the wheel
in 2003,

my dream car turns out to be
a bit of a nightmare.

It never occurred to me,
for example,

that I'd need a hammer
to change gear,

or that depressing the clutch would be
a lot easier if I got a friend to help me.

It's absolutely baking hot
in here,

though I've got the window
fully open,

and there's also a really
alarming smell of petrol.

And here's another thing, we're here
driving through leafy Hertfordshire,
and I'm told it's very pretty.

And it looks very pretty
through the windscreen,

but can't be quite so sure
out of the side,

and there is
a rear-view mirror up there

and there is, in fact,
a rear window.
But it's very small.

It's sort of like watching your
television through your letterbox.

God in heaven,
this is hard work.

I'm going to stop
for a cup of tea.

Right, let's have a quick
recap on the dream car.
The seat is crippling,
the controls are murderous,
I'm too hot, I'm deaf,

I've been poisoned,
I can't see,
and I can't park.

This is what "going to hell in
a handcart" probably feels like.

And it looked so good
on the poster.

In fact,
I wish it had stayed there.
I'm absolutely gutted.

But you know what, it's
not the car's fault, it's mine.

I've broken a golden rule. You never,
ever meet your childhood heroes.

Roger Moore, Lamborghini
Countach, Brian Cant.
Stick with the memories.
They're just better.
So, you're a shattered man.
That's my youth gone.

And I've got
even worse news for you.
Oh, no!

Do not tell me that
that's a ladyboy.
Her name is Steven.
Steven.

Actually,
it's even worse than that,

because until now, I've had a
Nobel Peace Prize for parallel parking.

- Mmm-hmm.
- And obviously, I made a complete hash of it in that.

But we have put a camera
where the mirror is,

and I just want you to be sure
that you understand, see,
just how difficult that was.

Steve or whatever her name is could actually
be sunbathing naked on here and, you know,

I wouldn't have
seen that either.

You wouldn't
have a clue.

- Well, the thing is, James, I can park a Countach.
- Can you?

And I've got a couple of cones
here and I'm going to prove it.

We're going to put one there,
okay?

And I'm going to put
the other one over here.

And I will be able to get
that car into this space,
no problem at all.

- Right.
- You don't think so?
You don't think so?

I... This could be
a bit of a laugh.
Right, I'm in.

And you can see the problem, you
certainly can't see out of the back.

But the extraordinary thing
about a Countach
is that...
Ooh, that's a good sound.

You can actually drive it
while not being in it.
And we're off!
How about that?

This was a technique developed
at the Lamborghini factory

which I've modified slightly for use
here, I'm not wearing sunglasses.
That's the difference.
I am in!

And that is how
you park a Countach.
Now. Now,
time for a confession.

A confession because when
we first started Top Gear,

we thought it would be a really
good idea, in the interest of fairness,

to make sure our
test track was always wet

so it was the same
for all the cars we tested.

Thing is, good idea, but we
made a complete hash of it.

All we were left with was a
really big bill for a water tanker

that wasn't big enough
to soak the whole track.

Seriously,
it was just like all dry

with some strategically placed
deep puddles at odd corners.

And that is why,
in the first programme,

the Lamborghini Murcielago, with
dead Stig at the wheel, set a time of 1.29.

Now we always knew
it could do better than that.

So, we sent fresh Stig out
on to a dry track

to see what the Murcielago
can really do.
So we're off the line.

It's four-wheel drive, remember,
so not much wheel spin,

but once it's moving,
look at it go!

Into the first corner.
Look how flat it corners.

Down towards Chicago
and that's practically level.

Hard on the brakes down here,
listen, it'd go down through the gears.

That is looking fast
and smooth and stable.
That's a lovely bit of Bach.

Unless you're The Stig, of course,
then it's the music from a cigar advert.

Now down towards the
Hammerhead, will it understeer?

Will it hack?
Absolutely, listen to that!
Oh, that's magnificent.

Heading towards the Follow
Through of course, now.
Will he lift, will he take it?

Flat out, I think. Slight
tap on the brakes, maybe.

Already well up
on its previous time,

will fresh Stig keep the pace
up into the penultimate corner?

Absolutely flat and level, that
grip's astonishing. Through Gambon,
and across the line in...
Well now, this is important,

because the Zonda,
which is our fastest car ever,

- is a 123.8.
- Which is a fantastic time.

And the Koenig...
is 123.9.

- So...
- It's close at the top.
It's done it!

It's the fastest car ever
around the Top Gear test track.
That is amazingly fast!

We always knew it would be, and I
was really looking forward to the moment

because, of course, you now
can't put that on there.

Ah, you'd love to think so, big fellow,
but you're wrong, because look...
Oh, that is...

- I wondered why we were doing it in this corner today.
- I had a word.

There you go, look at that. The only
thing faster than the Murcielago, 123.7,

is a jet fighter.
That's a quick thing.

Absolutely. Now,
it's time to meet our guest.

He's a comedian,
he's an actor,
and he made his name over here

by pretending to be a sort of American
country boy from the deep south.

So, please feel free to whoop
and fly your guns in the air

and develop an unnatural
attraction toward your sister.

Ladies and gentlemen,
Rich Hall!
How are you?
Have a seat.
Ah, now.

Before we get cracking
on the whole car business,

I don't think anybody here could
guess, if we gave them a million years,
what your first job was.

I was... I worked for the United
States Meteorological Service
as a hurricane namer.

So your job was to wait
for a hurricane to come
and then give it a name.
Very high-stress job.

Um... I held the position
for two years.

We really wouldn't get busy
until about September.

The reason I was fired was for giving
them names... Jugs. I called one Jugs.

I was really trying to...
I was trying to

give the hurricane names,
you know, something...

- Marmaduke?
- It's not as easy as it sounds because, uh...

You've got to
study the hurricane, and uh,
